sentence:
Glycolysis
Glycolysis (Figure 1a) is the initial step in cellular respiration and takes place in the cytoplasm.

Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP)
The pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) (Figure 1b) is a metabolic pathway that occurs parallel to glycolysis in the cytoplasm of cells.

Then, pyruvate enters the TCA cycle (Figure 1c) by two pathways: it is either converted into acetyl-coenzyme A (acetyl-CoA) by pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) or transformed into oxaloacetate (OAA) by pyruvate carboxylase (PC).
For instance, αKG can be converted into glutamate, a key precursor for amino acid and nucleotide synthesis (Figure 1d).
Similarly, when citrate is exported to the cytoplasm, it is converted into acetyl-CoA by ATP citrate lyase (ACLY), which is vital for lipid metabolism (Figure 1e).

Glutaminolysis
Glutaminolysis (Figure 1d) is a mitochondrial pathway that generates energy through the degradation of glutamine, the most abundant amino acid in the body.

Lipid Metabolism
Acetyl-CoA serves as the precursor for de novo fatty acid synthesis (Figure 1e) in the cytoplasm.
As cancer cells disseminate, they encounter diverse microenvironments and must adapt to secondary sites (Figure 2).
The three main pathways affected are glycolysis, glutaminolysis, and lipid metabolism (Figure 1).

Unlike the prevalent anaerobic glycolysis observed in many cancer cells within oxygen-deprived TMEs, brain metastatic cancer cells might exhibit a metabolic shift favoring the OXPHOS pathway (Figure 1).
This survival was attributed to the activation of alternative metabolic pathways, including gluconeogenesis and increased glutaminolysis (Figure 1).
Lipid metabolism plays an important role in BM (Figure 1).

Regulation of Cancer Metabolism by Oncogenes and Tumor Suppressors
Metabolic reprogramming in metastatic cancer cells is tightly regulated by oncogenic and tumor suppressor gene mutations (Figure 3).

Current Preclinical Models of Brain Metastasis to Test New Therapies
The metastatic cascade (depicted in Figure 2) is a complex multistep process that comprises local tissue invasion, intravasation into the circulatory system, extravasation to brain pre-metastatic sites, and colonization of the metastatic site.
